name: Stone Tablet Winged Buddha
description: Though traces of prehistoric settlement exist, Babylon’s development as a major city was late by Mesopotamian standards; no mention of it existed before the 23rd century BCE.

name: Stone Decorative Carved Totem

name: Jade Masked Totem
description: This artifact was identified by many Chinese archaeologists to be part of the ancient kingdom of Shu, specifically the Sanxingdui culture, linking the artifacts found at the site to its early legendary kings. References to a Shu kingdom that can be reliably dated to such an early period in Chinese historical records are scant (it is mentioned in Shiji and Shujing as an ally of the Zhou who defeated the Shang), but accounts of the legendary kings of Shu may be found in local annals.

References to a Shu kingdom that can be reliably dated to such an early period in Chinese historical records are scant (it is mentioned in Shiji and Shujing as an ally of the Zhou who defeated the Shang), but accounts of the legendary kings of Shu may be found in local annals.

name: Jade Dragon Eye Totem
description: According to the Chronicles of Huayang compiled in the Jin Dynasty (266–420), the Shu kingdom was founded by Cancong. Cancong was described as having protruding eyes, a feature that is found in the figures of Sanxingdui.

name: Porcelain Flower Vase
description: The vase first appeared in the temples of the Tang dynasty (608–917 AD) as a holy water vase. The shape was then popularized during the Song dynasty, and was mainly used as a wine vessel.
